row.field: There are a variety of possible economic incentives, like carbon caps, tax credits, CAFE laws, etc.
We should not act rashly, and need more information.
Tax on carbon emissions that is the same for all regions and all sectors.

Hybrid system that combines cap and trade system with a base carbon tax. Some versions include a safety valve will allows for issuing additional permits if market price rises to some predefined level above tax.

Advocated by William Nordhaus in A Question of Balance (Yale Press, 2008).
Carbon tax should be levied across the board, but reimbursement offered on a per capita basis.
Major, possibly irreversible impacts (see the IPCC Technical Report on impacts)
Impacts will be gradual and humankind can adapt (see for example Mendelsohn of Yale School of Forestry)
Costs substantial and potentially catastrophic(as much as 20% of global GDP per Stern Review )
According to Nordhaus as little as 1% of GDP with 2 degrees of warming and as little as 5% with 4 degrees (see here p. 26)
550 ppm stablization costs ?1% global GDP ± 2%(International Energy Agency, IPCC, Stern Review, McKinsey)
Costs could be “order of magnitude higher”(primarily due to unanticipated implementation challenges, see Weyant Rev of Env Ec & Policy 2, no. 1 (2008) p. 86 )
Capping carbon and letting companies trade permits is like the successful cap and trade programs for SO2 and NOX.
Creates algae blooms, which consume more CO2

The McKinsey Global Institute has developed a curve that shows

- the overall emission reduction potential and

- the cost per ton of emission reductions

for the different emissions reductions technologies.

Energy efficiency, for example, has a "negative" net cost (that is, it generates a positive return on capital investment). This implies that we should choose a technology portfolio that achieves the desired reductions using the least costly approaches.

For more see

http://www.mckinsey.com/mgi/publications/Investing_Energy_Productivity/index.asp

Socolow's wedge analysis states that a broad array of current technologies can be deployed to reduce emissions by 50% through 2050. This suggests that the world could achieve deep emission cuts through scale adoption of existing technologies. For more see

http://www.princeton.edu/~cmi/resources/CMI_Resources_new_files/CMI_Stab_Wedges_Movie.swf

NASA climate scientist James Hansen advocates rapid adoption of energy efficiency technologies, plus R&D on renewables, carbon capture and storage, and 3rd generation nuclear. For more see

http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/20081121_Obama.pdf
Regulating companies behavior
What is required is a complete redefinition of the legal / economic entity that a corporation is.
Individual behavior will change when the price signals in the economy reflect the true costs of greenhouse gas emissions.
Cultural and institutional influences have been greatly underestimated as potential policy tools. These powerful levers can be utilized to spur behavioral change at the household level.
Subsidize investments in green technology.
The Rodale Institute has demonstrated deep, prolonged soil carbon sequestration through organic farming methods. http://www.strauscom.com/rodale-release/

This plan assumes the continuation of current practices, which result in rapid growth of greenhouse gas emissions throughout the 21st century due to reliance on a fossil fuel based global energy system.

Global emissions trajectories are based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) A1FI scenario, which posits rapid future global economic growth and a fossil fuel intensive energy system.

Regional emission allocations are based on the International Energy Agency's (IEA's) World Energy Outlook 2008.

This is one of two scenarios presented in the World Energy Outlook 2008 http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2008.asp, an annual study prepared by the International Energy Agency (IEA) http://www.iea.org/.

IEA's members are the countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) http://www.oecd.org/, which includes all of the world's industrial economies.

The 450 ppm scenario is designed to limit the average global temperature increase to 2 degrees Celsius, the limit recommended in the Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/ar4-syr.htm of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) http://www.ipcc.ch/.

In the 450 ppm scenario global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions peak in 2020 and begin to decline through 2030. Regional emission trajectories are as follows:

  • Emissions in the OECD countries decline 40% from 2005 levels by 2030.
  • Emissions growth in developing countries through 2030 is limited to 15 to 20% above 2005 levels.

    • The 450 ppm scenario also envisions aggressive action to reduce deforestation and increase CO2 sequestration through the planting of new trees.

    Other elements of the plan include:

  • Regional and national cap-and-trade systems playing an important role.
  • CO2 price of $180 per metric ton in 2030.

    • IEA estimates that through 2030, the plan will cost less than 1% of global GDP:

  • More than $9 trillion in investments will be required above the levels forecasted in the baseline scenario, an amount equal to 0.55% of global GDP over the period.
  • This additional investment will be offset by $5.8 trillion in fuel savings through 2030, an amount equal to 0.34% of global GDP.

This plan is based on proposal put forward by the United State Climate Action Partnership (USCAP) http://www.us-cap.org/, a group of 23 large corporations and 5 non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

USCAP's Blueprint for Legislative Action http://www.us-cap.org/blueprint/overview.asp has called on the United States and other leading industrial countries to commit to greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction targets of 40 percent by the year 2030 and 80 percent by the year 2050.

USCAP's memorandum on international climate negotiations http://www.us-cap.org/pdf/Climatewire_Article.pdf note the need for ""a flexible

framework recognizing the strong diversity among major economies." It goes on to call for binding absolute economy-wide reduction targets for developed countries while allowing developing countries a range of binding policy commitments taking into account national capacities, circumstances and policy approaches."

Based on these principles, this plan envisions that emission growth in the developing countries will be significantly slower than in the Business as Usual scenario. But 2050 emissions will be 50 percent above 2005 levels for the rapidly developing countries and nearly twice 2005 levels for other developing countries.

USCAP focuses primarily on emission reduction targets, so this plan does not envision significant changes in deforestation or substantial increases in CO2 sequestration throught tree growth.

Brief description

July 2009 agreement by G8 calling for 50% global reduction in emissions and 80% reduction in emissions from developed countries by 2050.

Background

In July 2009, leaders of the Group of 8 (G8) countries met in L'Aquila, Italy. Climate change was a major issue on the agenda.

Emission targets

The G8 declaration issued at L'Aquila called for:

-50% emission reductions globally by 2050

-80% emission reductions in developed countries by 2050

-emission reductions "significantly below business-as usual" in developing countries

The declaration also called for "robust aggregate and individual mid-term reductions."

    • Brief description

    July 2009 agreement by G8 calling for 50% global reduction in emissions and 80% reduction in emissions from developed countries by 2050.

This plan involves radical cuts in emissions by 2050, along with effective elimination of deforestation and substantial increases in natural CO2 sequestration from the planting of new trees.

This plan addresses the concerns expressed by some experts, such as NASA climate scientist James Hansen, that the 450 ppm stablization target advocated by the IPCC and IEA is too high. Hansen and others have called for a return to the 350 ppm atmospheric concentration of CO2 that prevailed prior to the industrial revolution. This is a tall order, since concentrations today are nearly 400 ppm.

This plan calls for developed country emissions in 2050 to be 95% below 2005 levels and for developing country emissions to decline between 65 and 75% by 2050. It also calls for the maximum feasible reductions in deforestation and the maximum feasible increases in CO2 sequestration from new tree planting.

Model run by Jason Jay, MIT Sloan

This plan attempts to achieve the Hansen/McKibben goal of 350 ppm stabilization. Hansen believes this will avoid the worst impacts of climate change and actually be sustainable and stable, without triggering positive feedback loops.

This is evidenced in the temperature graph - this model run is one of the few (perhaps the only) in which temperature actually starts to level off by 2100.

With the C-ROADS model, the only way to get to 350 is to floor all the emissions parameters, taking 99% of carbon out of the economy. This is not probable; it therefore highlights the limits of the model and the gravity of the situation. What radical innovations are required to accomplish this? What is outside the model boundary, for example carbon sequestration through agriculture and aquaculture, and geo-engineering?

Like the 80% model, this one necessarily involves radical cuts in emissions by 2050, along with effective elimination of deforestation and substantial increases in natural CO2 sequestration from the planting of new trees.

This plan addresses the concerns expressed by some experts, such as NASA climate scientist James Hansen, that the 450 ppm stablization target advocated by the IPCC and IEA is too high. Hansen and others have called for a return to the 350 ppm atmospheric concentration of CO2 that prevailed prior to the industrial revolution. This is a tall order, since concentrations today are nearly 400 ppm.

We need a national energy efficiency resource standard.

From the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy (http://www.aceee.org/pubs/e091.htm):

The United States is currently faced with many challenges: finding ways to help Americans save money, decreasing the rate of unemployment, and battling global warming, all in the midst of an economic crisis. Energy efficiency is one of the most effective, short-term and long-term resources that can address all of these issues. The implementation of an Energy Efficiency Resource Standard (EERS) is a proven mechanism proven to encourage productive investments in greater levels of energy efficiency.

Energy efficiency is the cheapest, fastest, and cleanest source of energy. This report highlights the importance of energy efficiency and the various market barriers that have limited the use of energy efficiency, discusses current state actions, and explains how an EERS works to achieve large energy savings. Most importantly, this report summarizes the potential savings that the United States might attain through the adoption of a national EERS as determined by a recent ACEEE analysis and explains the methodology supporting the analysis.

The current proposals for a federal EERS, House of Representatives Bill 889 (H.R. 889), sponsored by Representative Edward Markey (D-MA), and Senate Bill 548 (S. 548), sponsored by Senator Charles Schumer (D-NY), are both known as the Save American Energy Act. These bills call for distribution utilities throughout the country to demonstrate 15% electricity savings and 10% natural gas savings by 2020.

The energy saved through the proposed federal EERS could power almost 48 million households in 2020, accounting for about 36% of the households in the United States. Moreover, this level of energy savings will save Americans almost $170 billion, create over 220,000 jobs and reduce greenhouse gas pollution by 262 million metric tons while eliminating the need to build 390 power plants.

An EERS focuses on natural gas and electric utilities, encouraging continually increasing energy savings over time. Currently, nineteen states are implementing a state-based EERS. Policy actions at the federal level are necessary to strengthen the continued development and implementation of EERS at the state level and expand this policy to all 50 states.

This "pie-in-the-sky" technology is 45 years from producing commercial electrical power, and 30 years ago, it was 30 years away. We're still not sure we can produce electricity from fusion, but if we can, we'd have a nearly limitless and clean source of energy. Fusion differs from traditional (fission) nuclear power because helium is the primary product of the reaction: no long-lived nuclear waste to be managed for hundreds of thousands of years!

Revisions from IEA scenario

According to the IPCC, to stay below 450 ppm, GHG emissions need to drop dramatically by 2050: 50% from current levels worldwide, 75% from current levels in developed countries. This is hard to model, so the assumption is that developed countries drop by 75% and developing countries increase by half of the IEA scenario.

IEA scenario description

This is one of two scenarios presented in the World Energy Outlook 2008 http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2008.asp, an annual study prepared by the International Energy Agency (IEA) http://www.iea.org/.

IEA's members are the countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) http://www.oecd.org/, which includes all of the world's industrial economies.

The 450 ppm scenario is designed to limit the average global temperature increase to 2 degrees Celsius, the limit recommended in the Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/ar4-syr.htm of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) http://www.ipcc.ch/.

In the 450 ppm scenario, global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions peak in 2020 and begin to decline through 2030. By 2030 emissions in the OECD countries decline 40% from 2005 levels, while emissions growth in developing countries through 2030 is limited to 15 to 20% above 2005 levels.

The 450 ppm scenario also envisions aggressive action to reduce deforestation and increase CO2 sequestration through the planting of new trees.

Regional and national cap-and-trade systems play an important role in the 450 ppm scenario. The scenario forecasts a CO2 price of $180 per metric ton in 2030.

The IEA projects that through 2030, the 450 ppm scenario will require more than $9 trillion in investments above the leves forecasted in the baseline scenario, an amount equal to 0.55% of global GDP over the period. This additional investment will be offset by $5.8 trillion in fuel savings through 2030, an amount equal to 0.34% of global GDP.

Personal trade-able CO2 limits would asign each citizen a personal CO2 annual permit, equal to the per capita average now.

Only citizens would be issued with such permits, a proportion of which could then be traded on a real time carbon market.

All businesses and corporate activity, as well as those individuals wishing to exceed their annual entitlement, would bid for excess permits to enable economic activity but would then need to adapt their behaviour over time as personal carbon limits (PCL's) converged on a single world wide PCL for all countries.

All people are equal = 1 PCL, ultimately say 1 ton of carbon per head per year.

Instead of stunting economic growth, requiring developed countries to invest a minumum of 3% of GDP in sustainable and carbon reduction technologies. This will allow for large decreases in the CO2 output of developed countries without severe economic stagnation or problems. In addition the technology can be applied to developing countries to allow for sustainable growth. Although cannot be the only action, it is still necessary to enforce restrictions on carbon emissions in both developed and developing countries, this will help prevent ression and commercial losses while saving our planet.

By hhunter

This is a refinement on the "organic farming" solution. Organic is an ideology and a certification system, not a management system that measurably improves environmental benefit. Sustainable agriculture is a less ideological concept, which most people agree should be based on outcome measurements rather than organic means. How much carbon is being sequestered in the soil? How much NO2 emission from fertilizer is avoided? How much methane emission is avoided?

It may turn out that organic practices produce the best outcomes, but it is likely that the most sustainable agriculture will be a combination of the following:

  • Good plant genetics that increase yield with less fertilizer input, since excess NO2 from fertilizer use is a major greenhouse gas.
  • Conservation tillage, which leads to less rapid decay of organic material and increase in soil carbon.
  • Integrated Pest Management requiring less use of pesticides.
  • Better Agricultural Practices such as crop rotation that increase the nitrogen and carbon levels of the soil thus reducing both CO2 and NO2 emissions.

Shells of scallops and other molluscs are made of Calcium Carbonate and their growth is a natural carbon sequestration method. It works particularly well in tandem with other aquaculture such as tilapia. In degraded marine ecosystems, shellfish can filter and clean the water, producing food, local livelihoods, and carbon sequestration.

http://www.thefishsite.com/articles/615/carbon-sequestration-potential-of-shellfish

Plan described by Drew Jones of Climate Interactive http://climateinteractive.org at TEDx event in Asheville, NC 8/30/09:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CTS9RY1z_i8&feature=player_embedded#t=186

Key elements

  • Developed countries cap CO2 emissions in 2015 and reduce them 7% annually starting in 2020
  • Developing countries cap CO2 emissions in 2020 and reduce them by 7% annually staring in 2025
  • Developing country emission reductions are enabled by technology transfer and funding from developed countries
  • Major reductions in deforestation and increases in tree planting

    • (Note: The video uses the C-ROADS model, which has greater functionality than C-LEARN. In the "Actions" tab of this plan, the emission reductions described in the video are translated into the appropritae C-LEARN inputs).

Rough approximation of measures recommended by the Mission 2013 class at MIT (Solving Complex Problems, part of the MIT Terrascope programme) as outlined in its Mission Protocol. More details are available at https://wikis.mit.edu/confluence/display/mission2013/Mission+Protocol (certificates required).

The 2000-watt society (2,000-Watt Society) is a vision, originated by the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zürich at the end of 1998, in which each person in the developed world would cut their over-all rate of energy use to an average of no more than 2,000 watts (i.e. 17,520 kilowatt-hours per year of all energy use, not only electrical) by the year 2050, without lowering their standard of living.

The concept addresses not only personal or household energy use, but the total for the whole society, divided by the population.

Two thousand watts is approximately the current world average rate of total energy use. This compares to averages of around 6,000 watts in western Europe, 12,000 watts in the United States[1], 1500 watts in China, 1000 watts in India, and only 300 watts in Bangladesh.[2] Switzerland itself, currently using an average of around 5,000 watts, was last a 2000-watt society in the 1960s.

It is further envisaged that the use of carbon based fuels would be ultimately cut to no more than 500 watts per person within 50 to 100 years.

The vision was developed in response to concerns about climate change, energy security, and the future availability of energy supplies. It is supported by the Swiss Federal Office of Energy[3], the Association of Swiss Architects and Engineers, and other bodies.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000-watt_society

OECD scenario Key principles - keep average global temperature increase at 2°C (3.6°F) above pre-industrial levels - CO2 concentrations maximizing at ~450 parts per million
emission reduction Targets by 2050: - 80% in developed country - 50% in global emission - Developing countries that have a large share of global emissions to set binding targets - 20% reduction in deforestation by 2050 but no appreciable aforestation

Developing economies scenario
Key principles & targets
- principle of "common but differentiated" responsibilities (UNFCC): major historical emitters do more than countries that are developing today - 90% reductions
- Developing countries agree to reductions in energy intensity (energy used per unit GDP) but not absolute targets; emissions in 2050 are 40-50% lower than under the Business as Usual scenario, but are still 30-50% higher than in 2008 - Developed countries fund substantial aforestation activities, at 50% of the maximum levels articulated by IPCC to increase carbon sequestration capacity equivalent to 10% of 2050 emissions
The Buisness as usual scenario. Countries would maintain their current levels of emissions output. No disruption to the current energy economy.

Commitments negotiated at the Climate Interactive's Copenhagen Climate Exercise event held in Atlanta on January 29, 2009:


  • Developed countries fossil fuel emissions peak next year and begin to decline steadily by the middle of the next decade.

  • Fossil fuel emissions from developing countries experiencing rapid industrialization peak toward the end of the next decade and begin to decline late in the 2020s.

  • Fossil fuel emissions from the rest of the world peak next year and begin to decline gradually at the end of the next decade.

  • Emissions due to deforestation decline by more than half by 2050.

Plan envisions an 80% reduction in global CO2 emissions by 2050, with per capita emissions also converging by that date.

This plan was introduced at the end of the Atlanta event, as an approach that had the potential to meet the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) objective of stabilizing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations "at a low enough level to prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system."
Some areas will get more, some will get less. This can cause a substantial increase in migration.
This plan lays out a plausible technology roadmap toward a low carbon future.
This plan is not aggressive enough and would lead to dangerous temperature increases of almost 4 degrees Celsius by the year 2100.
This plan is incomplete, since it does not specify targets for the developing countries.
The world does not currently have the political will to adopt such an aggressive plan.
Even though this plan may not be adopted, it is important to advocate for it as a way to broaden the conversation about what is possible.
Developing countries will be in a few years the major contributors of global CO2 emissions. Thus, unilateral reduction by rich countries will be insufficient
This is a good starting point, the first time the G8 heads and other political leaders have acknowledged the gravity of the problem and the need for action.
Without a clear set of incentives for developing countries and funding from rich countries, these targets will be impracticable.

This plan makes clear the kind and magnitude of risks we may face in the future if some natural positive feedback loops bringing further CO2 increase will be activated by current emissions and warmimng trends.

Yes, but it relies excessively on the good functioning of cap & trade systems. There is no evidence those systems will work properly and without international agreements, emissions will just be offset to countries who will not adopt severe cap&trade regulations.
It is just crazy to sit and do nothing given the magnitude of the risks humanity could face in the near future if global warming is not controlled.
this plan is based on the wrong value that economy is a priority over the environment. But how can economy thrive without being sustainable?
this plan seems like a good approach. my one argument is that I believe that developed countries should reduce their emissions by 75%. I'll try a new scenario like that.

Climate change has started. Evidence shows, with a very high confidence level, that in every continent, the physical and biological systems are already being affected by recent climate changes (Rosenzweig, C, 2007). These changes are particularly noticeable by regional temperature increases. Although the effects on humans are not yet discernable (ibid.), the anthropologic and natural dimensions are interconnected. The natural ecosystem provides tangible and intangible benefits that should be taken into account when the option to maintain status quo is on the table. Not to mention intergenerational rights. Rosenzweig, C., G. Casassa, D.J. Karoly, A. Imeson, C. Liu, A. Menzel, S. Rawlins, T.L. Root, B. Seguin, P. Tryjanowski, 2007: Assessment of observed changes and responses in natural and managed systems. Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds., Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, 79-131.

Although cap and trade is a necessary market instrument for emission reduction, the way allowances are initially distributed and the value of each carbon ton are essential attributes of success. Depending on how the market runs and is regulated, emission reduction may only occur if the price of improving energy efficiency overcomes the cost of paying for carbon tons.

Many energy efficiency options can be implemented with a net positive benefit (positive payback). For example, see McKinsey's latest analysis. It's a good overview of energy efficient potential options.

The USCAP Scenario seems to be a regional / national scenario, and lacks interdependencies at a global level. If imports of goods don’t follow the same cap and trade market rules imposed to US companies based in the US that will create market inequalities. At the lights of carbon cap and trade regulation, perhaps an embodied carbon tax, taking into account the product life cycle, could be beneficial for the American economy (as a hole) and contribute to the global objective of climate change.

While it's true that the potential magnitude of risks to humanity is enormous, the particular effects of climate change are highly diffuse. What does it mean to a single individual if the Greenland ice sheet melts or the risk of malarial disease increases? We have to remember that it's not necessarily crazy for each human to dismiss climate impacts as "someone else's problem." We should focus hard on understanding this point of view and finding ways to change such sentiments or mitigate clmate change in spite of them.
This seems like a relatively measured and sane approach. One MAJOR challenge: getting policymakers to agree on the mid-term emissions cuts (like reductions in 2030).

Keep an eye on California: Governor Schwarzenegger announced his goal for 80% emissions reductions from 1990 levels by 2050; pretty similar to this scenario. California may not reach this goal, but by setting it so ambitiously, it may come a long way toward at least meeting the requirements of the 450 ppm scenario. If, as the Governor predicts, this policy leads to a boon for California cleantech business, we may again see California paving the way for changes in federal political will.

Nuclear power has problems (especially cost and waste management challenges), but it's the only currently commercially available source of carbon-free baseload electricity we have. We'll have to aggressively build more nuclear plants, at least as a bridge toward a renewable energy takeover.

We need to be careful about organic farming. Sometimes, farming organically means using a lot more land to produce smaller quanitities of food. Emissions could go up as a result of larger land areas to harvest and longer distances for distribution if land is used less efficiently. Does someone know of a study of the emissions life-cycle impacts of organic farming?

How would organic farming reduce the effects of emissions? I see this more as a mitigation strategy?? Although I prefer to eat organic whenever possible, and it does potentially save on petroleum based fertilizers, unless it is locally grown and purchased, and there is some sort of standardized process of labeling foods as "organic", I'm not sure if it does actually reduce emissions at all. I agree with Lara that we would need to see a life-cycle impact study of organic farming.

All nations must take their share of responsibility for global responses to pressing global problems, as Obama said. In my opinon, the only way is the co-operation. Thus the G8 would be a great starting point, waiting for G20.

This is too sane an approach. If we don't do something even more aggressive, we won't have enough of an impact to reduce the negative impacts on billions of people. Somehow, we need to get not only countries but also companies, NGOs, and individuals to collectively achieve a radical shift.

Is it fair to segment the BRIC countries from the rest of the developing world? On the one hand, there are developing countries whose emissions we should be really concerned about. On the other, there are countries that are in severe need of basic resources, and imposing strict limitations on their emissions might keep them in a poverty cycle.

I agree that we probably don't have the political will to adopt this plan and that countries, organizations, and individuals will need incentives (and a really thorough understanding of what's going on) to make it work. But instead of assuming these targets are impracticable, I wonder if we could ask what it would take to implement them?

Let's go for it. I believe that a change in agricultural production could have a huge impact toward the success of this plan. We need to set the goals high, but use realistic mechanisms to achieve them.

If corporations started internalizing the negative externalities of their activities, their product prices would more accurately reflect the total, long-term cost of the product (for example, maybe the cost of soda should include a distribution of the costs of treating diabetes). To do this, corporations will have to completely recalibrate so that their stock prices are not the only indicator of success. Some companies have already begun moving in this direction. If they successfully make the transition to "enlightened corporate behavior", perhaps others will see the possibility of setting prices, measuring profits, and developing products in ways that are beneficial in a long-term, global scope.

I'd agree. Even with the existing evidence of climate change, many just don't care because it doesn't impact them. For example, the cash for clunkers program seemed to be a success as the government had a huge backlog of trade-ins to be processed. However, I personally know a number of poeple that refused the participate simply because of the conveninece of having a nice, spacious, air conditioned vehicle that gets them from point A to point B. How do we reach out to these people and/or what can be done to reach approaching emissions goals understanding that human behavior is a complex thing to manipulate?
I'm just wondering how this would actually be achieved - what laws and mechanisms have to be put in place for people's behavior to change so drastically?

I'd agree. It is too difficult change human behaviour. I listened in a television program that a research group is investigating on new technology product that could destroy the CO2. Perhaps, the future is in this new technology.
Actually the concern applies mostly to big emitters like China and India.
Yes, we may set ambitious targets and later be satisfied if we reach them just partially. But this would severely undermine the credibility of policies in the long term.

And what is the impact of this plan on economics issues? I think that the economy is the force that drivers the human behaviour and choice. A good plan could be foresee not only CO2 reduction but also an economic benfits.
In developing countries some think they have the right to pollute as developped countries did extensively after the industrial revolution. So they may not be willing to spend from their pocket.

Also I like this plan, because it seems to produce an increasing in global temperature of about 2°. The real challenge for world politicians is to identify suitable solutions to help rapidly developing countries to reduce their emissions.

Even when developing countries are funded by the developped world, the way the subsidies are spent should be monitored in a way that wouldn't hurt people's national pride. Look at eastern european countries heavily funded by EU. There is still a high level of corruption in many of them. Who knows where those EU fundings end up!

With the current models of costs, this plan looks like the best alternative to minimize both damage costs and mitigation costs. The closest competing plan is the G8 plan, but the G8 plan has a risk of much greater mitigation costs without much addiitional benefit in reduced damage costs.

Solar power should be used more, it is a very effective way to use the sun's energy. We must being to use renewable energy sources to keep the world clean.
I agree, we need to start using more renewable energy sources, like wind, hydro and solar.

Have you ever thought about the fact that climate change is a normal process. Millions years ago this place was under hundreds of kilometers of ice... and without human activity... it melted! Maybe we are in a normal process and we cannot change anything about it... maybe...

Natural processes play a role, but there is strong evidence that human activity is having an greater impact than natural processes. The earth's mean global temperature (MGT) increased approximately 0.6 degrees Celsius (1.1 degree Fahrenheit) between 1860 and 2000, and scientists estimate that this increase is more rapid than any that has occurred over the past millenium due to natural processes. For more details, see Figure 2.3 from the IPCC's Third Assessment Report (2001): http://www.grida.no/publications/other/ipcc_tar/?src=/climate/ipcc_tar/vol4/english/022.htm
Interesting idea that is philosophically aligned with the per capital equity stance the developing countries have been advocating in the UN climate talks.

I agree - baseload is the issue. Wind and solar are critical but intermittent. We need new baseload already, with coal plants running at excess capacity and reaching end of life. As much as I hate to say it given my environmentalist roots, we have to go nuclear. But we have to do it smart - standardize the plants to facilitate learning and improvement, and reprocess as much of the waste as possible, with increasing efficiency.

The best power plant is the one you never had to build. We are so far from achieving the potential in EE. There are aggressive policies needed, however, to bridge the information asymmetries and transaction costs that impede the market for EE. We need tough building codes based on increasing standards. We need mandatory energy audits at the time of building sale with a clear labeling scheme. We need financing mechanisms for EE improvements where debt stays with the property via the tax or utility bill. We need "all cost effective efficiency" requirements and decoupling for utilities. And we need innovative business models to provide financial support to grass roots outreach and handholding through the retrofit process.

I created a "sustainable agriculture" alternative to counter these problems. Jason Clay from WWF says "organic is not sustainable" because it requires more land for the same amount of food, thus putting pressure on forests and other natural ecosystems. We need to be outcome driven not ideology driven.
I think that it should be little impact because the greater the impact the more it changes.....
This is a better framing of the approach than organic farming.
The 75% reduction for the developed countries is in line with commitments already articulated by most members of the OECD.

Even though it may be difficult to do, it is necessary for the sake of our planet. The most recent science says that 350 ppm is the maximum limit for sustained life on this planet. The question cannot be "how possible is this?" or "how much does this cost?", but instead "are we willing to change or would we prefer to drastically alter the climate, thus destroying life as humankind has known it?"

I believe that people have the capability to do anything, so long as they have the will. Bill McKibben's 350.org movement proves that we do have the collective will to reverse our emissions trends. That movement organized over 5,000 events in over 180 countries, and was the largest climate day of action in history. Beyond that grassroots movement, companies now have the will to reduce their carbon emissions, and governments are increasingly more willing to set strict carbon emissions reduction goals. Of course the US does not have a cap-and-trade system yet, but states have been taking the lead in regulating carbon emissions through various mechanisms.
Right, but may not be possible. The IEA 450 ppm plan might not be enough though. It is only asking these countries to meet half their original commitment.
Something in between this and the 450 ppm developed country plan would be better.

Unfortunately stabilization at 450ppm does not align with the latest science, which sets a max of 350ppm. If we stabilize at levels above the maximum limit of 350ppm, there will be extremely high human, social, and financial costs adapt.
This plan lays out a plausible, and inspiring, path toward long term sustainability.

This option has no natual alies, NASA says after the Space Station is done - can't get congress to go for two big projects at the same time. DOE is tied up with nuclear energy. Many Enfironmentalists see it is big science that competes with ground solar. Untilites see it as too big to fund themselves. Nuclear folks know it is a serious long-term competitor. So, only Japan has come out for it. Wirelessly transmition of energy could also take night time nuclear surplus production from France and trasmit via satellite to regions in the dday time. Space solar power could produce enough for the world without the storage requirements of some ground alternatives, is not weather dependent, is 24 hours a day without producing GHGs or nuclear waste. With enough solar satellited, the baseload electricy of the world could be managed on a global basis in orbit getting the optiomal electricy at anytime and location, granted will take many years. Initial environmental and health studies were good, but should be done more extensively.
